title: Excel VLOOKUP Function Explained
excerpt: Learn how to use VLOOKUP to search vertically within a dataset and return matching values quickly.
content:
üîç VLOOKUP ‚Äì Vertical Lookup

The VLOOKUP function searches for a value in the first column of a range and returns a value from another column in the same row.

=VLOOKUP(lookup_value, table_array, col_index_num, [range_lookup])

Example: =VLOOKUP(A2, B2:D10, 3, FALSE)

title: Excel HLOOKUP Function Explained
excerpt: HLOOKUP searches horizontally across the top row of a range to find data matches.
content:
üìä HLOOKUP ‚Äì Horizontal Lookup

The HLOOKUP function searches the top row of a range and returns a value from a specified row index.

=HLOOKUP(lookup_value, table_array, row_index_num, [range_lookup])

Example: =HLOOKUP('Q1', A1:E5, 3, FALSE)

title: Excel FILTER Function
excerpt: Learn how to dynamically filter data in Excel using conditions without needing manual sorting.
content:
üßÆ FILTER ‚Äì Dynamic Data Selection

FILTER returns an array of data that meets specific criteria. It‚Äôs dynamic and updates automatically.

=FILTER(array, include, [if_empty])

Example: =FILTER(A2:D20, C2:C20>5000)

title: Excel UNIQUE Function
excerpt: Remove duplicates instantly using Excel's UNIQUE function for clean datasets.
content:
üéØ UNIQUE ‚Äì Remove Duplicates

The UNIQUE function extracts distinct values from a range or array.

=UNIQUE(array, [by_col], [exactly_once])

Example: =UNIQUE(A2:A50)

title: Excel QUERY Function (Google Sheets)
excerpt: Use SQL-like commands in Google Sheets to query your data tables dynamically.
content:
üß† QUERY ‚Äì SQL for Spreadsheets

The QUERY function lets you use SQL-like syntax to manipulate your spreadsheet data.

=QUERY(data, 'SELECT A, B WHERE C > 5000 ORDER BY B DESC', 1)

Example: Retrieve all rows where salary > 5000, sorted by name.

title: Excel SORT Function
excerpt: Automatically sort data in ascending or descending order using the SORT function.
content:
üìà SORT ‚Äì Auto Arrange Data

SORT organizes your data without manual sorting, and updates dynamically.

=SORT(array, [sort_index], [sort_order], [by_col])

Example: =SORT(A2:B20, 2, -1)

title: Excel XLOOKUP Function
excerpt: XLOOKUP is the modern replacement for VLOOKUP and HLOOKUP with more flexibility and accuracy.
content:
üöÄ XLOOKUP ‚Äì Modern Lookup Tool

XLOOKUP searches a range or array and returns a corresponding value, both vertically and horizontally.

=XLOOKUP(lookup_value, lookup_array, return_array, [if_not_found], [match_mode], [search_mode])

Example: =XLOOKUP(A2, B2:B10, C2:C10, 'Not Found')

title: Excel IF Function
excerpt: Perform logical tests and return results based on TRUE or FALSE conditions.
content:
‚öñÔ∏è IF ‚Äì Conditional Logic

The IF function checks whether a condition is met, and returns one value if TRUE, and another if FALSE.

=IF(logical_test, value_if_true, value_if_false)

Example: =IF(A2>50, 'Pass', 'Fail')

title: Excel INDEX Function
excerpt: The INDEX function returns the value of a cell within a specified range based on row and column numbers.
content:
üî¢ INDEX ‚Äì Get Cell Value by Position

The INDEX function returns the value of a cell inside a range given a row and column number.

=INDEX(array, row_num, [column_num])

Example: =INDEX(A2:C10, 3, 2) ‚Üí Returns the value from the 3rd row and 2nd column of the range.

title: Excel MATCH Function
excerpt: Find the position of a value within a range using the MATCH function.
content:
üéØ MATCH ‚Äì Find Position of a Value

The MATCH function searches for a specified item in a range and returns its relative position.

=MATCH(lookup_value, lookup_array, [match_type])

Example: =MATCH('Apple', A2:A10, 0) ‚Üí Returns the position of 'Apple' in A2:A10.

title: Excel INDEX + MATCH Combination
excerpt: Combine INDEX and MATCH to perform powerful lookups more flexible than VLOOKUP.
content:
üß© INDEX + MATCH ‚Äì Advanced Lookup

Use INDEX and MATCH together to find values based on both row and column lookups.

=INDEX(return_range, MATCH(lookup_value, lookup_range, 0))

Example: =INDEX(C2:C10, MATCH(A2, B2:B10, 0)) ‚Üí Returns matching value from column C where B matches A2.

title: Excel SUMIFS Function
excerpt: Add numbers that meet multiple criteria using the SUMIFS function.
content:
‚ûï SUMIFS ‚Äì Conditional Addition

SUMIFS adds numbers that satisfy one or more conditions.

=SUMIFS(sum_range, criteria_range1, criteria1, [criteria_range2], [criteria2])

Example: =SUMIFS(C2:C100, A2:A100, 'North', B2:B100, '>500') ‚Üí Adds sales where Region='North' and Value>500.

title: Excel COUNTIFS Function
excerpt: Count cells based on multiple criteria using the COUNTIFS function.
content:
üî¢ COUNTIFS ‚Äì Conditional Counting

COUNTIFS counts the number of cells that meet multiple conditions.

=COUNTIFS(criteria_range1, criteria1, [criteria_range2], [criteria2])

Example: =COUNTIFS(A2:A50, 'East', B2:B50, '>100') ‚Üí Counts all records from East region with values >100.

title: Excel CONCAT Function
excerpt: Combine text from multiple cells into one using CONCAT or CONCATENATE.
content:
üîó CONCAT ‚Äì Combine Text

The CONCAT function joins values from multiple cells into a single string.

=CONCAT(text1, [text2], ...)

Example: =CONCAT(A2, ' ', B2) ‚Üí Joins first and last name with a space.

title: Excel TEXTJOIN Function
excerpt: Join multiple text strings with a specified delimiter using TEXTJOIN.
content:
üí¨ TEXTJOIN ‚Äì Join with a Delimiter

TEXTJOIN merges multiple text items with a delimiter (like comma or space).

=TEXTJOIN(delimiter, ignore_empty, text1, [text2], ...)

Example: =TEXTJOIN(', ', TRUE, A2:A10) ‚Üí Joins all non-empty cells from A2:A10 with commas.

title: Excel TRANSPOSE Function
excerpt: Flip rows and columns in a dataset using TRANSPOSE.
content:
üîÑ TRANSPOSE ‚Äì Flip Rows and Columns

The TRANSPOSE function switches rows to columns and vice versa.

=TRANSPOSE(array)

Example: =TRANSPOSE(A1:C3) ‚Üí Converts rows to columns.

title: Excel SEQUENCE Function
excerpt: Generate a sequence of numbers dynamically with SEQUENCE.
content:
üî¢ SEQUENCE ‚Äì Auto Number Generator

The SEQUENCE function creates an array of sequential numbers.

=SEQUENCE(rows, [columns], [start], [step])

Example: =SEQUENCE(10, 1, 1, 1) ‚Üí Generates numbers 1 to 10 in a column.

title: Excel LET Function
excerpt: Simplify complex formulas by defining and reusing variables using LET.
content:
üß© LET ‚Äì Define Variables in Formulas

LET assigns names to calculation results, improving readability and performance.

=LET(name1, value1, calculation)

Example: =LET(x, A1*2, x+10) ‚Üí Doubles A1, then adds 10.

title: AVERAGEIFS Function
excerpt: Average with multiple criteria.
content: =AVERAGEIFS(D2:D10, B2:B10, ">50", C2:C10, "<200") ‚Äî Calculates conditional averages.

title: TRANSPOSE Function
excerpt: Switch rows to columns dynamically reverse.
content: =TRANSPOSE(A1:D4) ‚Äî Converts rows into columns.

title: SPARKLINE Function
excerpt: Mini chart inside a cell.
content: =SPARKLINE(B2:B10) ‚Äî Displays a trendline for data in one cell.

title: LET Function
excerpt: Define and reuse variables in formulas.
content: =LET(x, A1*2, y, B1*3, x+y) ‚Äî Uses named variables to simplify complex logic.

title: LAMBDA Custom Function
excerpt: Create your own formulas inside Excel.
content: =LAMBDA(x, x*10)(5) ‚Äî Returns 50 by defining an inline custom function.

title: Advanced QUERY Joins (Sheets)
excerpt: Join multiple sheet tables using QUERY.
content: =QUERY({Sheet1!A1:D; Sheet2!A1:D}, "SELECT * WHERE Col4 > 10") ‚Äî Merges and filters multiple sheets.
